awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Zoonotic Risks at the Human-Primate Interface: Behavior, Nutritional Status, and Immune Function
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation project will investigate how differences in human behavior, gender, subsistence patterns, nutrition, and immune function influence the transmission and progression of zoonotic illnesses from nonhuman primates, such as monkeys, gorillas, and chimpanzees, to human groups. The project's anthropological and primatological context and expertise provide a unique opportunity to understand these complex relationships among human groups who rely on forest resources but vary in terms of culture and nutritional access. In addition, improved understanding of the cultural, behavioral, and biological processes that promote novel zoonotic infections in humans helps inform scientific advancements and public health research on epidemics. The project will support training for a female graduate student and underrepresented groups in STEM research fields, and will foster international research, science outreach, and public health collaborations. 

This project takes place over a 15-month period in a protected forest reserve in the southwest corner of Central African Republic where human communities rely on wild meat and forest vegetables as primary sources of protein and nutrition, and where the diminishing availability of wildlife and other forest resources threaten food security and public health outcomes.  The study focuses on a unique mix of communities and cultural groups to understand multiple factors that may influence zoonotic emergence -- human contact with nonhuman primates, varied nutritional access, increased food security, and increased population density. Researchers will use behavioral and dietary surveys, measurements of nutritional status, analysis of hemoglobin levels, and analysis of immune function to understand zoonotic risk.  Zoonoses threaten global health and security and are linked to the HIV epidemic, Ebola outbreaks in West and Central Africa, and Zika outbreaks in South America. By providing insight on variation in zoonotic risk across a single population, this project can help develop more effective global health policies for preventing and controlling new epidemics.

por.por_cntn:
This project used a unique multidisciplinary approach toward understanding complex dynamics of disease emergence. Using behavioral, nutritional, immunological, and epidemiological methods, it explored dynamics of disease risk in a Central African forest at the human-wildlife interface. Over a 16-month period from 2017-2018, behavioral and biological data were taken with informed consent from over 1,000 people living in Dzanga Sangha Protected Areas (DSPA) in Central African Republic (CAR). DSPA is located in a biodiverse yet extremely food insecure area that borders Cameroon and the Republic of Congo. The study population included indigenous groups as well as long-term and short-term migrants from other parts of CAR and West/Central Africa. While the population is diverse, nearly everyone in DSPA relies on forest resources to meet their daily nutritional and economic needs.

This study used behavioral and dietary intake surveys, measurements of nutritional status, and immunological and epidemiological analyses of dried blood spot samples from participants to analyze the relationships among behavioral, nutritional, and immunological risks of novel zoonotic disease transmission from wildlife to humans. Behavioral and dietary surveys were completed by participants across four rounds of data collection to gain insight on ways behavioral risks of exposure to zoonotic diseases and dietary access differ by ethnicity, gender, village, age, and season. During two of these data periods, which included the heights of the rainy and dry seasons, biological data were collected and matched with behavioral and dietary data. Biological data included anthropometric measurements of nutritional status and collection of dried blood spot (DBS) samples. DBS samples were analyzed at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta, GA for presence of primate retroviruses known to transfer from nonhuman primates (NHP) to humans.

While the degree of dietary diversity and nutritional status differed across indigenous and migrant groups, results showed that food insecurity and poor nutrition were issues faced by most of the study population regardless of ethnicity, gender, village, and age. This study also found that most of the study population lacks critical access to protein sources, including wild meat. Analyses of DBS samples revealed lower hemoglobin levels among the indigenous BaAka and showed that women regardless of ethnicity were more likely than men to have hemoglobin levels below WHO standards. Low dietary diversity and poor nutritional status place the population at higher risk for poor immunological function. About 10% of study participants reported high behavioral risk factors for exposure to zoonotic diseases, including hunting and/or butchering NHP, keeping NHPs as pets, or direct injury from a NHP. Biomolecular analyses of DBS spots suggest zoonotic transmission of primate retroviruses in the study population. The data together suggest that behavior, dietary access, and nutrition all play an integral role in zoonotic disease risk among the study population.

The findings of this study contribute to greater scientific understanding of the complex dynamics underlying zoonotic disease emergence, particularly in vulnerable and marginalized populations. A greater understanding of these dynamics further informs global health initiatives and policies to prevent novel disease emergence, thus reducing overall disease burden and improving global health outcomes.
